--- title: Portal package: "@chakra-ui/portal" image: "components/portal.svg" description: Renders a React subtree in a different part of the DOM. --- Portal is used to transport any component or element to the end of `document.body` and renders a React tree into it. Useful for rendering a natural React element hierarchy with a different DOM hierarchy to prevent parent styles from clipping or hiding content (for popovers, dropdowns, and modals). It supports nested portals ## Import ```js import { Portal } from "@chakra-ui/react" ``` ## Usage ```jsx function Example() { return ( I'm here, This text is portaled at the end of document.body! ) } ``` ```tsx function Example() { return ( I'm here, This text is portaled at the end of document.body! ) } ``` ### Using a custom container You can render the contents within a portal to a different DOM node, instead of the default `document.body`. Pass the `containerRef` prop and set its value to the `ref` of the container you'd like to use. ```jsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return ( I'm here, Portal: This text is portaled to the yellow box!
Container: Hey,
 ) } ``` ```tsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return ( I'm here, Portal: This text is portaled to the yellow box!
Container: Hey,
 ) } ``` ### Nesting Portals You can also nest multiple portals within themselves, this will create a nested DOM hierarchy to make it easy to create nested modals, popovers, etc. ```jsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return (
Parent: Hey welcome, Child: I'm attached to my parent portal
) } ``` ```tsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return (
Parent: Hey welcome, Child: I'm attached to my parent portal
) } ``` ### Opting out of portal nesting In some cases, you might not want portal nodes to be nested to their parent portals. To opt out of this, pass `appendToParentPortal` and set it to `false` ```jsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return (
Parent: Hey welcome, Child: I'm going to document.body
) } ``` ```tsx function Example() { const ref = React.useRef() return (
Parent: Hey welcome, Child: I'm going to document.body
) } ``` ## Props
